Award.AwardTitle: Data Driven, Engagement Based, Adaptive Learning, Growth Mindset Pedagogy Informed Course Redesign with Early Research Experiences for STEM Student Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities - Undergraduate program provides support to design, implement, study and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the numbers of students and the quality of their preparation by strengthening science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education and research. This project at Clark Atlanta University provides a strategic approach to redesigning foundational STEM courses to increase student success. The project is guided and informed by an on-going evaluation, as well as by an internal advisory committee.

The goals of the project are to improve students' mastery and use of foundational STEM concepts, improve student learning outcomes, and increase the number of students matriculating in graduate programs after graduation. Evidence-based activities are designed to improve retention, persistence, and graduation rates of STEM majors. The strategies employed are: adaptive learning technologies and supplemental instruction; workshops for students on self-efficacy and growth mindset pedagogy; faculty development workshops on mentoring undergraduate students and teaching differently, self-efficacy and growth mindset pedagogy; and early research experiences for students. School of Education faculty will assess and study which of these interventions or combinations thereof are most effective.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this project at Clark Atlanta University, we have redesigned General Chemistry I and II and Calculus I, foundational STEM courses, implementation digital and adaptive learning courseware, supplemental instruction (SI), and provided students cognitive and non-cognitive skills development, and early undergraduate research immersion to improve student learning outcomes, retention, progression to graduation, and matriculating in graduate programs after graduation.  This project supports CAU's commitment to course redesign to improve student learning outcomes, increasing retention, persistence, and graduation rates of STEM majors.  In addition to direct course redesign, we have conducted workshops for students on self-efficacy and growth mindset pedagogy and faculty development workshops on mentoring undergraduate students, teaching with digital and adaptive learning courseware and SI, self-efficacy, and growth mindset pedagogy.

We have found that the course redesign, including the implementation of digital and adaptive learning courseware in General Chemistry I and II and Calculus I, led to an increase in the percentage of students earning A and B and a decrease in the percentage of students earning C. However, this intervention did not reduce the percentage of students who earned a D or F or withdrew from the courses.  We found that the utilization of the rich data analytics available from the digital and adaptive courseware supported intrusive advisement, leading to a reduction in the percentage of students who earned a D or F or withdrew from the redesigned courses and a corresponding increase in students success (earning an A, B, or C). There was also a strong correlation between student engagement in SI and course success.  Based on the improved students learning outcomes in foundational courses and students' requests, digital courseware is now being implemented in upper-level STEM courses. We are continuing to track student progression through their degree program to determine if our hypothesis that improved student learning outcomes, as reflected in earning higher grades, in foundational STEM courses leads to improved retention in STEM and degree completion.  

Twelve students engaged in undergraduate research during the academic year six students during the summer with CAU STEM faculty and graduate student mentors. These students have presented over twenty presentations at local, regional, and national meetings. We are continuing to track student progression through their degree program to determine if our hypothesis that early student research experiences improve retention in STEM and degree completion.  

We have shared the initial results for our course redesign and other interventions via presentation and publications; such that other HBCUs and 4-year institutions can benefit from our experience in redesigning their foundational STEM course to improve student success.  Increased STEM student success at HBCUs supports the development and maintenance of a diverse workforce in a technology-based economy that responds to 21st century national needs and global competitiveness. Implementing digital and adaptive courseware in foundational STEM courses and faculty development supported the rapid transition to remote teaching and learning in response to the COVID 19 pandemic during the 2020 spring semester.
